learn by letting them go

1232.41.text: is to set some kind of a frame.

1234.01.text:
To not go in and actually do
it for them and show them,

1238.15.text:
but say, here's the frame, in
this case experimentation,

1239.94.text: here's some ideas or here's a place

1242.54.text: you might go learn about it.

1244.39.text:
Or in this case, there's a
group of people at Whirlpool

1246.99.text:
that are experts in this.
They're Six Sigma Black Belt.

1249.82.text: And then letting them do that

1251.70.text:
and then come back, and then
I think the leadership role

1261.72.text:
- Yeah, I agree with
everything that's been said.

1263.43.text: I guess I would add a couple of things. In my mind, I think of the scientific method,

1269.26.text: and I think the scientific method—

1272.72.text: having a hypothesis. And I think one thing

1276.57.text:
that's difficult about a
lot of interpersonal skills

1278.87.text:
is maybe the hypothesis is
that, I am unable to do that,

1284.01.text:
or, I will feel really uncomfortable
doing that, or whatever.

1286.88.text:
And that's a hypothesis
about capabilities.

1290.09.text:
Another hypothesis is
one about effectiveness.

1294.53.text:
If I do this, then it will
be effective, ineffective,

1299.94.text:
And I think to be clear minded
about what you're trying

1302.60.text:
to get out of any kind of
activity that you're doing.

1305.34.text: I think the issue about capabilities

1307.51.text: is very different than the issue

1310.07.text:
And then to try something
different, as Harry was saying,

1314.98.text: and one of the things is that

1317.08.text:
sometimes there are just
things that you can do

1322.04.text: and I think one of the things that I know

1323.89.text: that Harry believes in a lot

1325.75.text: is that you have to behave differently

1329.14.text:
because a situation in which
you're in front of the room,

1332.19.text: people are expecting you to take command,

1335.05.text: is very different than a situation

1336.20.text: where we're in a group of peers

1338.13.text:
or something in which we
have somebody new or whatever.

1342.35.text:
And so you have to
develop the capabilities

1344.76.text: of being in lots of situations

1347.60.text:
but you also have to
develop the capabilities

1349.89.text: of figuring out what's right to do

1354.68.text:
- One of the things that gets
in the way of experimentation

1356.84.text:
is the sense that people tend
to seek confirming evidence,

1360.98.text:
which means if, for example, I
think George doesn't like me,

1365.45.text:
in a group situation
I'm not going to do anything

1371.11.text: I will probably not say very much

1373.65.text:
because my belief is he's
not gonna listen to me.

1376.83.text:
It's important that people
seek disconfirming evidence,

1380.61.text: and that's the way science evolves.

1382.37.text:
And in the laboratory
courses that I've run

1386.47.text: in the last two or three years,

1391.34.text: at how many people are surprised

1396.87.text: and the belief sets they had were wrong.

1401.85.text:
people are going to distance
themselves from me,

1405.49.text:
and so they start to
do that and people say,

1407.19.text:
gee, that's a really smart
thing, Nancy, say more.

1411.16.text: And so, I think that's a habit

1414.12.text: that often needs to be broken.

1417.95.text: a lot of kinds of things . . .

1419.79.text:
people talk themselves out of
doing certain kinds of things

1426.66.text: because they think they're not gonna work

1428.59.text:
or they think that they're
not going to be able

1431.63.text: and sometimes they're right, and of course

1434.58.text:
And you're never gonna
learn that you're wrong,

1437.09.text:
that you can't do
something, unless you try it,

1442.48.text:
But you gotta try it and
see if it works or not.

1446.69.text: How important is it to have a mentor

1448.30.text: if you want to become a better leader?

1450.12.text: - Well, I'm sitting here with two mentors

1451.82.text:
so I have to say it's
important, and I believe it.

1454.76.text:
I think mentors are, they're
part of the feedback process.

1462.47.text: and they have time to spend.

1464.95.text:
- Does that mean people
in the same company

1468.96.text: - I think in some ways sometimes people

1472.09.text:
in the same company are
extraordinarily helpful

1473.77.text:
when it comes to tacit
knowledge and domain knowledge.

1476.93.text: If somebody says, by the way,

1478.42.text:
let me tell you something
that happened 10 years ago

1480.27.text: that is still a part of the culture,

1482.47.text:
you better pay attention to
it. That's very relevant.

1486.26.text:
to talk to somebody in a
completely different field.

1489.52.text: So I think opening oneself up to

1491.28.text: asking for help, and I think sometimes

1496.99.text:
leaders get into
difficulty 'cause they say,

1500.75.text:
well, I'm a leader, I
shouldn't ask for help

1503.62.text:
And I think that's really
not the case at all.

1506.70.text: At the same time, I would just say

1511.29.text:
I think that teachers and
mentors can be helpful to a point,

1514.63.text: but I think when all is said and done,

1517.42.text:
leadership is a personal
commitment to one's self

1523.76.text:
and a mentor can sometimes
say, you should do this.

1527.03.text: You should do that. You should do this,

1532.14.text: But sometimes you have to say,

1533.42.text:
well, that may be a
characteristic of those people,

1536.05.text: but that's not my leadership style.

1539.64.text: So I think one has to . . .

1541.34.text:
you've probably had a lot of
experience with that, Nancy.

1544.17.text:
- Well I was just thinking,
that's very well said,

1546.34.text: because I think mentors and teachers

1549.50.text: can take you to a point

1550.96.text: and then as you said, you have to,

1553.33.text:
it's a performance art,
you have to perform,

1556.07.text: And so I think both are really important,

1558.88.text: but I think it was really well said.

1563.16.text:
what about leading in a
period of great disruption

1566.93.text: Are there specific kinds of skills

1569.58.text: that work well in those situations?

1574.20.text: because in some sense I'm not sure

1575.61.text:
when we're not leading
in that environment,

1578.41.text: I just can't remember a time

1579.66.text: when everything was calm and peaceful.

1582.21.text: But I think there are important skills,

1584.34.text:
and I think one of the
things leaders need to do

1586.34.text:
is think about patterns
to get up on the balcony

1589.91.text:
and to kind of understand that
there is a pattern to things.

1593.24.text:
There is kind of, there are
cycles and seasons to things.

1597.20.text:
And being able to have
that confidence—not ego—

1599.87.text:
but that confidence to help
other people understand

1601.91.text:
we're gonna get through
this. There is light

1603.81.text: at the end of the tunnel.

1604.81.text:
So I think having that
leading-from-the-balcony view

1607.86.text: in times when things are really difficult,

1610.95.text:
when it's really hard, is
really an important trait.

1614.82.text:
- How do you balance that
with the sort of getting down

1615.95.text: into the details that Harry talked about?

1617.96.text: - I actually think you have to do both.

1620.57.text: I think, you have to be able to get down

1623.55.text: on the playing field but not do the work.

1626.79.text: You have to understand it enough

1628.74.text: and then you have to lead from the balcony.

1631.21.text:
And I think where a lot of
leaders fail is the balcony

1633.78.text: because a lot of us are promoted

1635.95.text:
because of the way we
are on the playing field,

1638.83.text: and so getting up above and understanding

1641.70.text: that there's a system behind things

1643.87.text:
and there are connections
that you need to understand,

1646.10.text:
I think that's where
leaders really struggle.

1650.36.text:
to come back to this idea of technical
skills and interpersonal skills:

1653.12.text: we all can think of examples of companies

1655.42.text:
that were not meritocracies,
that were not lead

1658.14.text:
necessarily by the
smartest, most able people,

1660.72.text:
but there was something about
the leaders of those companies

1663.03.text: that got them to that position.

1664.72.text: Does that mean that interpersonal skills

1666.53.text:
are more highly regarded
at a certain point?

1669.17.text: - I don't know, I mean, I think

1672.48.text:
business is always going
to be a combination of these—.

1675.11.text:
I mean, if you don't
understand your business

1677.72.text:
and strategy and all
those kinds of things,

1681.16.text:
On the other hand, if you can't
get people in an organization

1685.21.text: mobilized behind what you're trying to do,

1687.84.text: whether or not it makes sense,

1689.84.text: that's not going to be effective either.

1691.77.text: So I think, of course, the hard part is

1694.40.text:
those things are oftentimes
seen as two different ways

1697.36.text: of thinking, two different kinds of skills,

1699.23.text: and you gotta do both of those things.

1702.11.text:
And you have to . . . I think
what makes it even harder

1706.08.text:
is that good leaders have
to make the assessment,

1711.18.text: is this mostly a vision thing,

1713.70.text: where what I have to do

1716.25.text: Or is it mostly a people thing?

1718.72.text:
Or is it something where
it's people at the beginning

1721.21.text: and then vision or vice versa.

1725.50.text:
on both of those kinds of
dimensions is what's necessary.

1730.61.text: - In some ways things get done,

1732.71.text: not just because of the leader

1734.89.text:
but because the leader
has created a culture

1740.31.text:
that lots of people in the
organization take responsibility,

1746.61.text:
The leader may get all the
attention and the credit,

1749.22.text: but it's to some extent the result

1754.73.text:
and often not just
intellectually but emotionally.

1758.57.text: - OK, well it seems like a leader

1761.03.text:
should basically be able to
do everything extremely well.

1764.11.text:
It sounds like the summary of
the conversation we've had,

1766.20.text: but we'll talk more about this.

For the moment, our time,
